Fields:
Staphlycoccus aureus key features  | 1. Gram positive 
2. Beta haemolytic 
3. Coagulase positive 
4. Mannitol positive
Sort Field: Staphlycoccus aureus key features

Fields:
Staphylococcus aureus symptoms  | 1. Can cause patchy infiltrates on Chest X-ray and causes bacterial pneumonia 
2. Can cause soft tissue infections like impetigo, furuncles, carbuncles and cellulitis
3. infective endocarditis (running camel) 
4. Rapid onset food poisoning from food like mayonaise and meats contaminated by exotoxin
5. Septic arthritis (bandage around camel) 
6. Exfoliative toxin also produced which causes scalded skin syndrome
Sort Field: Staphylococcus aureus symptoms

Fields: Staphylococcus aureus toxic shock syndrome  | Superantigen toxin which connects the MHC II with the antigen and the CD4 cell to cause fever, desquamative rash and sepsis
Sort Field: Staphylococcus aureus toxic shock syndrome

Fields:
Staphylococcus aureus treatment  | Nafcillin is effective against non-MRSA staph aureus (pencil) 

Vancomycin is effective against MRSA
Sort Field: Staphylococcus aureus treatment

Fields:
Staphylococcys epidermidis features | Gram positive coccus 
Susceptible to novobiocin (which is why you can see the navel) 
Catalase positive 
Coagulase negative
Sort Field: Staphylococcys epidermidis features

Fields:
Distinguishing between staphylococcus and streptococcus species  | Catalase positive for staph 

Catalase negative for strep
Sort Field: Distinguishing between staphylococcus and streptococcus species

Fields:
Staphylococcus epidermidis infection  | 1. Prosthetic joints 
2. Associated with indwelling catheters 
3. Can cause prosthetic valve endocarditis
Sort Field: Staphylococcus epidermidis infection

Fields:
Difference between Staphylococus aureus and Staph epidermidis & saprophyticus  | Staph aureus - coagulase positive (moses and the red sea) 

Staph epidermidis - coagulase negative (jello)
Sort Field: Difference between Staphylococus aureus and Staph epidermidis & saprophyticus

Fields: How does Staphylococcus epidermidis commonly affect prosthetic valves and IV catheters? | Produce biofilms (extracellular polysaccharide matrix)
Sort Field: How does Staphylococcus epidermidis commonly affect prosthetic valves and IV catheters?

Fields:
Staphylococcus saprophyticus features  | Gram positive
Catalase positive 
Coagulase negative 
Urease positive 
Novobiocin resistant
Sort Field: Staphylococcus saprophyticus features

Fields: Staphylococcus saprophyticus infections | Urinary tract infections in young sexually active females
Sort Field: Staphylococcus saprophyticus infections

Fields: Treatment for staphylococcus epidermidis and saprophyticus? | Vancomycin
Sort Field: Treatment for staphylococcus epidermidis and saprophyticus?

Fields: Staphylococcus aureus virulence factor  | Produces protein A which binds to the Fc region of the antibody which prevents complement activation and phagocytosis
Sort Field: Staphylococcus aureus virulence factor

Fields:
Features of streptococcus pyogenes  | 1. Gram positive 
2. Beta haemolytic - hence the bulb 
3. Encapsulated - the pie is encapsulated
Sort Field: Features of streptococcus pyogenes

Fields:
Infection with Streptococcus pyogenes | 1. Red puffy gloves since group A strep is the most common cause of skin infections 
2. Streptococcal pharyngitis - strep throat 
3. Scarlet fever 
4. Rheumatic fever
Sort Field: Infection with Streptococcus pyogenes

Fields:
In scarlet fever for Strep A, what features are there? | 1. Guy in the back licking the strawberry - strawberry tongue 

2. Pyrogenic exotoxin which causes the fever 

3. This exotoxin can act as a superantigen which can cause streptococcal toxic shock syndrome 

4. SpeB causes necrotising fasciitis

5. Distribution due to the pyrogenic exotoxin is sand paper rash apart from the soles or the palms
Sort Field: In scarlet fever for Strep A, what features are there?

Fields: Virulence factor in rheumatic fever for streptococcus  | Hat with an M on it - inactivates complement and also causes the formation of cross reactive antibodies (molecular mimicry)
Sort Field: Virulence factor in rheumatic fever for streptococcus

Fields: Effect of streptococcus pyogenes on the heart  | Can cause rheumatic heart disease. Can cause mitral regurgitation and then mitral stenosis
Sort Field: Effect of streptococcus pyogenes on the heart

Fields:
Diagnosis of rheumatic fever  | JONES criteria 

Migratory polyarthritis (J for joints) 
Pancarditis (heart shaped) 
Subcutaneous nodules (design on the cupcakes) 
Rash with C shaped erythema (erythema) 
Sydenham chorea - rapid involuntary movement throughout the body
Sort Field: Diagnosis of rheumatic fever

Fields: Effect of streptococcus pyogenes on the kidney? | Glomerular knot - post streptococcal glomerulonephritis caused by depositions within the glomeruli which can cause nephritic syndrome
Sort Field: Effect of streptococcus pyogenes on the kidney?

Fields:
Prevention of rheumatic fever after strep throat? | Guy with the pencil - prompt treatment with penicillin 

but cannot prevent poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis
Sort Field: Prevention of rheumatic fever after strep throat?

Fields:
Other virulence factors for streptococcus pyogenes? | Streptolysin O - which can be used to diagnose strep throat 

Streptokinase which converts plaminogen to plasmin which prevents fibrin barrier
Sort Field: Other virulence factors for streptococcus pyogenes?

Fields: Streptococcus pyogenes and bacitracin? | Bacitracin sensitive
Sort Field: Streptococcus pyogenes and bacitracin?

Fields:
Streptococus agalactiae features  | Purple planet - gram positive 
Hippo on the floor with baby - hippurate hydrolysis positive 
Encapsulated 
Beta haemolytic lamp 
CAMP factor produced - enlarges region of haemolysis 
Bacitracin resistant (basset hound)
Sort Field: Streptococus agalactiae features

Fields:
Streptococcus agalactiae infection  | Helmet on baby's head - Number one cause of neonatal meningitis 

Red onesie - number one cause of neonatal sepsis 

Coughing baby - can cause pneumonia
Sort Field: Streptococcus agalactiae infection

Fields: Screening of Streptococcus agalactiae  | Pregnant women are screened for group B strep at 35-37 week gestation since GBS is the most common cause of neonatal meningitis
Sort Field: Screening of Streptococcus agalactiae

Fields:
Treatment for streptococcus agalactiae  | Spaceship held by 3 pencils 

If testsed positive for Strep agalactiae at 35-37 weeks, then intrapartum penicillin is delivered IV
Sort Field: Treatment for streptococcus agalactiae

Fields:
Features of streptococcus pneumoniae  | Think about sir pneumo in the knight tournament 
Purple banners - gram positive 
A knight tournament - alpha haemolytic 
Chin is exposed in helmet - Optochin sensitive
Bile soluble 
Encapsulated - wearing armour
Sort Field: Features of streptococcus pneumoniae

Fields:
Infection with streptococcus pneumoniae  | Rust colour on the chest plate of knight - lobar pneumoniae with rust coloured sputum 

Servant mopping - most common cause of MOPS (Meningitis, Otitis media, Pneumonia and Sinusitis)
Sort Field: Infection with streptococcus pneumoniae

Fields: What is the reason for why Streptococcus pneumoniae can infect the mucosa so easily? | Think about the IgA shield - can cleave at the hinge region so decreased effectiveness of IgA
Sort Field: What is the reason for why Streptococcus pneumoniae can infect the mucosa so easily?

Fields: Patients more at risk to Streptococcus pneumoniae? | Sickle cell disease patients - since it is an encapsulated bacteria and spleen affected in SCD
Sort Field: Patients more at risk to Streptococcus pneumoniae?

Fields:
Treatment for streptococcus pneumoniae? | Three axes flag - Ceftriaxone 
MaCROWlide
Sort Field: Treatment for streptococcus pneumoniae?

Fields:
Streptococcus viridans features  | Gram positive 
Non encapsulated - in the sketch not wearing armour 
Optochin resistant - chin is not exposed 
Bile resistant - the horses have shoes which allows it to resist the bile
Sort Field: Streptococcus viridans features

Fields: Streptococcus viridans infection | Mitre hat - can adhere to previously damaged heart valves (commonly mitral valve) - leading to endocarditis
Sort Field: Streptococcus viridans infection

Fields: How does streptococcus viridans cause infection? | Has a deck of cards - can produce dextrans which allows them to adhere to tooth enamel and fibrin aggregates
Sort Field: How does streptococcus viridans cause infection?

Fields: Streptococcus viridans and teeth  | Yellow teeth on donkey - can be the cause of dental caries
Sort Field: Streptococcus viridans and teeth

Fields:
Enterococcus faecium and faecalis features  | Gram positive 
Faecalis is responsible for 80-90% of enterococcal infections 
Green boots - can resist the bile so bile resistant
Sort Field: Enterococcus faecium and faecalis features

Fields: Growth medium for enterococcus  | Can be grown in 6.5% hypertonic saline
Sort Field: Growth medium for enterococcus

Fields: Infection with enterococcus faecium and faecalis  | Do U heart trees - can cause various infections including UTIs, endocarditis and biliary tree infection
Sort Field: Infection with enterococcus faecium and faecalis

Fields:
Treatment for enterococcus faecium and faecalis  | Remember the resisting into the van - thats because they have developed resistance to many antibiotics like vancomycin 

Think of the lines surrounding the van - linezolid and the tiger stripes as tigecycline
Sort Field: Treatment for enterococcus faecium and faecalis

Fields:
Bacillus anthracis and cereus features  | Gram positive - purple mountains behind them 

Line of ships - occur in chains 
Capsule (for other bacteria would be polysaccharide) but for bacillus anthracis it is made of a polypeptide (poly-gamma-d-glutamic acid) 
Produce spores - walnuts
Sort Field: Bacillus anthracis and cereus features

Fields: Bacillus anthracis cutaneous presentation  | Ring of fire - in the middle of the erythema, there is an area of necrosis
Sort Field: Bacillus anthracis cutaneous presentation

Fields:
Exotoxins from bacillus anthracis  | Think about the shields 

One shield has edema factor (EF) and also the tent - mimics adenylate cyclase which increases cAMP which increases dysfunction of phagocytes 

Another shield has lethal factor - protease that cleaves MAPK which leads to apoptosis, necrosis and death
Sort Field: Exotoxins from bacillus anthracis

Fields: Where is bacillus anthracis found? | Sheep wool - sometimes the spores would be carried within the animal wool
Sort Field: Where is bacillus anthracis found?

Fields:
Symptoms of bacillus anthracis  | Might have skin necrosis - with the ring of fire 
Bloody axe - haemorrhagic mediastinitis which would show widened mediastinum on x-ray (widened mast on boat)
Sort Field: Symptoms of bacillus anthracis

Fields:
Treatment for bacillus anthracis  | Viking boats with shields of flower and bicycle wheel 

fluroquinolones
Doxycyclines
Sort Field: Treatment for bacillus anthracis

Fields: Typical cause of bacillus cereus infection | Reheated rice - spore germination and production of exotoxin which leads to watery diarrhoea (guy eating rice towards the left)
Sort Field: Typical cause of bacillus cereus infection

Fields:
Features of Clostridium tetani  | Gas mask - obligate anaerobe 
Purple hues - gram positive 
Walnuts - spore forming
Sort Field: Features of Clostridium tetani

Fields: How do you usually get infected with clostridium tetani? | Puncture wounds from barbed wire or a rusty nail
Sort Field: How do you usually get infected with clostridium tetani?

Fields:
Clostridium tetani infection  | Trismus - paralysis of the jaw muscles 
Risus sardonicus (evil smile appearance) 
Arched back - arched monkey
Sort Field: Clostridium tetani infection

Fields:
Toxin from clostridium tetani  | Protease that cleaves the SNARE proteins  

Prevents the release of glycine and GABA from renshaw cells causing muscle spasms (think about the monkey with the wrench and the saw)
Sort Field: Toxin from clostridium tetani

Fields: Prevention of Clostridium tetani? | Tetanus vaccine which contains the deactivated tetanus toxin (also given with the diphtheria toxoid and pertussis vaccine)
Sort Field: Prevention of Clostridium tetani?

Fields:
Clostridium botulinum features  | Gram positive - purple hues 
Spore forming - using the nuts (rather than the walnuts) 
Guy in the gas mask - obligate anaerobe
Sort Field: Clostridium botulinum features

Fields: Where is Clostridium botulinum found? | Anaerobic condition of improperly canned food - which is why these bots are made of cans
Sort Field: Where is Clostridium botulinum found?

Fields: Clostridium botulinum infection  | Descending paralysis - with a limp neck and also starting from cranial nerves (so can have diplopia and ptosis)
Sort Field: Clostridium botulinum infection

Fields: Clostridium botulinum mechanism  | Produce a protease which cleaves the SNARE protein which inhibits the release of acetylcholine
Sort Field: Clostridium botulinum mechanism

Fields:
Infant botulism 

Where is it commonly found?  | Ingestion of spores - colonise the GI tract while in adults due to performed toxin so have floppy baby 

In honey
Sort Field: Infant botulism Where is it commonly found?

Fields:
Clostridium perfringens features  | Gram positive - purple hues 
Walnuts - spore forming 
soil - found in the soil 
Gas mask - obligate anaerobe
Sort Field: Clostridium perfringens features

Fields: Reason for clostridium perfringens infection | Very common cause is from military combat wounds. Think of the scene from a military zone
Sort Field: Reason for clostridium perfringens infection

Fields:
Infection with clostridium perfringens  | Think about the smoke in the background - skin and soft tissue infection that can lead to gas gangrene 

Alpha flag - alpha toxin which cleaves lecithin which damages the cell membrane (washing line) and causes the myonecrosis and haemolysis (tomatoes)

Fields: Investigation for clostridium perfringens  | Double fine zone - double zone of beta haemolysis when on blood agar (since both alpha and theta toxin have haemolytic activity)
Sort Field: Investigation for clostridium perfringens

Fields: First line treatment of Clostridium perfringens | Surgical debridement and think of the woman at the tomato stand with the pencil - penicillin

Fields: Clostridium perfringens and water | If drinking muddy water, late onset food poisoning (hence the slow sign) and watery diarhhoea
Sort Field: Clostridium perfringens and water

Fields:
Features of clostridiodes difficile  | Purple - gram positive 
Gas mask - obligate anaerobe 
Walnuts - spore forming 
Eating chocolate walnuts - transmitted by faaecol oral route
Sort Field: Features of clostridiodes difficile

Fields: Clostridoides difficle and washing  | Usually spores are resistant to alcohol based gels so wash hands with soap
Sort Field: Clostridoides difficle and washing

Fields:
Common cause of C. Difficile  | Antibiotics - disrupts the microbiome 

Think about the octopus - 'clean'damycin, fluoroquinolone, cephalosporin, penicillins and parasole (PPIs)
Sort Field: Common cause of C. Difficile

Fields: Clostridioides Difficile toxins  | A and B (annoying kids that act on the gummy bears) which are the mucosal cells and disrupt the cytoskeleton and destroy the tight junction.
Sort Field: Clostridioides Difficile toxins

Fields:
Clostridioides Difficile infection  | Pseudomembranous colitis 
Chocolate waterfall - watery diarrhoea 
White birds - leukocytosis and fever 
Big pipe with the chocolate in - can lead to toxic megacolon

Fields:
Testing for C. Difficile  | Using NAAT (Nucleic acid amplificationm usually PCR to look for the toxin encoding genes) 

Think of gnatts - which are the insects around the kid  

Also EIA test - for the glutamate dehydrogenase
Sort Field: Testing for C. Difficile

Fields: First line therapy for Clostridioides difficile infection  | Oral vancomycin - think of the van with the mouth on it
Sort Field: First line therapy for Clostridioides difficile infection

Fields:
Other treatments for C. Difficile infections | There is the the fiddler - fidaxomicin 

Metro with ivy - IV metronidazole
Sort Field: Other treatments for C. Difficile infections

Fields: What surgery can be done for C. Difficile infections? | Faecal microbiota transplantation (plants in pipe)
Sort Field: What surgery can be done for C. Difficile infections?

Sort Field: Histoplasma capsulatam associations

Fields:
Histplasma capsulatam infection  | Macro'cage' - macrophage phagocytize the yeast form of histoplasma capsulatum in the lungs 

and can cause calcification in the lungs and erythema nodosum

Fields: Histoplasma capsulatam testing  | Staglacite (red and yellow) can be detectd in the urine or in the serum
Sort Field: Histoplasma capsulatam testing

Fields: Histoplasma capsulatum microscope  | Oval cells within macrophage

Fields:
Disseminated histoplasmosis cause and symptoms  | immunocompromised 

Cave drawing with the large liver and spleen (hepatosplenomegaly)

Fields:
Treatment for histoplasma capsulatum  | Pine cones (coneazole) -azoles are effective 

In immunocompromised - drawing of amphibian (amphotericin B)

Corynebacterium diphtheriae features  | Gram positive - purple stadium 
Red and blue maracas - due to metochromatic granules

Fields:
Diphtheria infection  | Think about the bull in the background - can cause 'bull's neck' which is just severe lymphadenoapthy

Guy eating sausages - can cause nerve dmage - in the posterior pharyngeal wall and soft palate

Growing corynebacterium diphtheriae  | Cystine tellurite agar - think of the tele in the television of the arena

Prevention of Corynebacterium diphtheriae  | Toxoid vaccine in developed countries and has the inactivated diphtheria exotoxin (given with the tetanus toxoid and pertussis) 

injecting the bull

Fields:
Listeria monocytogenes features  | Santa's LIST 

Gram positive 
Beta haemolytic bulb at the top of the christmas tree 
Purple chrismtas lights falling off - tumbling motility 
Cat under hte table - catalase positive

Fields: Temperature listeria can grow  | Think of the icicles that are there at christmas time - can grow in temperatures of 0 degrees

Treatment for Listeria monocytogenes  | Christmas time - someone has received an amp for their present 

Ampicillin

Branching tree - filamentous bacilii 
Gas mask - since he is a soldier - so obligate anaerobe

Tuberculosis cactus - lesions can often be misdiagnosed as tb

Fields:
Dimorphism in histoplamsa? | Yeast in the heat, mold in the cold

Neisseria meningitidis features  | Red walls - think gram negative 
Set in college - easily spread in close quarters 
Think about MAC the private detective 
Encapsulated

Difference between Neisseria meningitidis and gonorrhoeae? | Think about the broken glass in Neisseria gonorrhoea - not encapsulated 

While the evidence in meningitidis is encapsulated

Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection | PID in women - chandelier (alight so think inflammed)

Fitz-Hugh Curtis band (hehe) 

Candle wax from the chandelier - causes mucopurulent discharge

Fields:
Go through the stages of iron deficiency in terms of the blood readings  |
  1. Initially since the body is depleted of iron - it uses its resources - so the current iron stores so the ferritin decreases. Since the body wants to transport the iron transferrin/TIBC increases as a result
  2. Then, the serum iron is depleted since the iron being used and saturation goes down since rather than being 1/3 now could be 1/6 since the iron is being used
  3. Normocytic anemia - body still wants to preserve the normal production (EARLY)
  4. Microcytic - running out of Hb - so therefore divides an extra time

During acidosis, complement is activated which causes the red blood cells to lyse

Fields:
Chediak-Hiagshi Syndrome Features |
Lack of this 'track' - so leads to neutropenia (can't move the organelles from one side to the other), giant granules (since the granules can't be transported anymore so just accumulate), defective primary haemostasis (dense granules in platelets) since again can't transport, peripheral neuropathy since such a long nerve that nutrients can't be transported, albinism (melanin can't be transported from melanocytes to the keratinocytes)
Mainly because of the lack of these tracks, lysosome can't fuse with phagosome

Fields:
Describe the normal pathway for how sodium is absorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule? | on basolateral membrane - think fo the mum swapping peanuts for bananna 

on the apical membrane - think of the helmet being swapped for peanuts (Na+/H+) 

Then these people go the race cars (bicarboante) to form carbonic acid 

This carbonic acid is then converted by the carbonic anhyrase into CO2 and H2O which diffuse into the cell 

Intracellular carbonic anhydrase converts teh H2O and CO2 back into the H2CO3 which dissociates and the H+ used for sodium reabsorption again and HCO3- to the basolateral (car pushed away)
Sort Field: Describe the normal pathway for how sodium is absorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule?

Fields:
How does axetazolamide work?

What effect does this have?  | Inhibits the carbonic anhydrase - so think of the car battery being inhibited  

Less CO2 and H2O reabsorbed - less of the H+ means less Na+/H+ exchange so less sodium reabsorbed so leads to natriuresis
Sort Field: How does axetazolamide work?What effect does this have?

Fields:
What do thiazide diuretics do?

What is their effect on calcium?  | They inihibit NaCl reabsorption at the apical membrane - leading to natriuresis

Fields:
Go through what happens in terms of the TPP in quiet breathing  | in quiet breathing - the alveolar pressure is going to be 0

Go through what happens to the intrapleural pressures in the different parts of breathing  | Starts as - 5
